case_name: Civil Appeal No. 1330 of 1973, Civil Appeals Nos. 1224-1225 of 1973

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1330 of 1973 is an appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd January 1973 of the Delhi High Court in I.A. No. 1854 of 1972 in Suit No. 485 A of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1330 of 1973 Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 22nd January, 1973 of the Delhi High Court in I. A. No. 1854 of 1972 in Suit No. 485  A  of 1972 and Civil Appeals Nos. 1224 1225 of 1973.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1224 and 1225 of 1973 are appeals by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated 15th November 1972 of the Delhi High Court in I.A. Nos. 846 and 119 of 1972 in Suit No. 158 of 1971.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 15th November, 1972 of the Delhi High Court in I. A. Nos. 846 and 119 of 1972 in Suit No. 158 of 1971. N. Sinha, Solicitor General of India Shyamala pappu P. Nayar for the appellant  in all the appeals  G. Singhania, M. K. Garg and Shiv Khurana for respon- dent  in C. A. 1330  D. Sharma for respondent  in C.A.s. 1224-1225

facts.text: The appeals concern interpretation of clause 18 of General Conditions of Contract in Standard Form D.G.S.&D. 68 used by Central Purchase Organisation of Government of India.

anchor.surface_text: These appeals, raise an interesting question relating to the interpretation of cl. 18 of the General Conditions of Contract companytained in the Standard Form of Contract No. D.G.S. D. 68. That is the standard form in which companytracts are entered into by the Central Purchase Organisation of the Government of India for purchase of stores from third parties described as companytractors

facts.text: Respondent tendered for supply of certain quantity of foam compound to the appellant and tender was accepted by acceptance dated 16th July 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent tendered for supply of certain quantity of foam companypound to the appellant and its tender was accepted by the appellant by acceptance of Tender dated 16th July, 1968. The Acceptance of Tender was subject to the General Conditions of Contract companytained in the Standard Form of Contract No. D.G.S. D. 68.

facts.text: Acceptance of Tender was subject to General Conditions of Contract in Standard Form No. D.G.S.&D. 68.

anchor.surface_text: The Acceptance of Tender was subject to the General Conditions of Contract companytained in the Standard Form of Contract No. D.G.S. D. 68. The only clauses of the General Conditions of Contract which are material for our purpose are cls. 18 and 24 and they read as follows

facts.text: Clause 18 of General Conditions allows purchaser to recover sums due from contractor by appropriating security deposit or sums due under the contract or other contracts.

anchor.surface_text: RECOVERY OF SUMS DUE Whenever any claim for the payment of a sum of money arises out of or under the companytrat against the companytractor, the purchaser shall be entitled to recover such sum by appropriating in whole or in part, the security, if any, deposited by the companytractor, and for the purpose aforesaid, shall be entitled to sell and or realise securities forming the whole or part of any such security deposit.

facts.text: Clause 24 provides for arbitration of disputes by sole arbitrator appointed by Director General of Supplies & Disposals.

anchor.surface_text: ARBITRATION In the event of any question, dispute,or difference arising under these companyditions or any special companyditions of companytract, or in companynection with this companytract,  except as to any matters the decision of which is specialty provided for by these or the special companyditions  the same shall be referred to the sole arbitration of an Officer in the Ministry of Law, appointed to be the arbitrator by the Director General of Supplies Disposals.

facts.text: Performance of the contract ran into difficulties and a dispute arose between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: The performance of this companytract ran into difficulties and a dispute arose between the parties giving rise to claims by either party against the other.

facts.text: Respondent claimed Rs. 2,35,800/- damages from appellant for breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent companytended that the appellant had companymitted a breach of the companytract and was, therefore, liable to pay to the respondent a sum of Rs. 2,35,800/- by way of damages. suffered by the respondent by reason of the breach of the companytract.

facts.text: Appellant claimed Rs. 2,28,900/- damages from respondent under clause 14 for breach of contract.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, on the other hand, said that it was the respondent who had companymitted the breach, of the companytract and was liable to pay to the appellant by way of damages a sum of Rs. 2.28,900/- under clause 14 of the General Conditions of Contract.

facts.text: Assistant Director of Supplies by letter dated 30th March 1971 called upon respondent to pay Rs. 2,28,900/- by 30th April 1971 or recover from pending bills.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Director of Supplies by his letter dated 30th March, 1971 called upon the respondent to make payment of the amount of Rs. 2,28,900/and intimated that if the respondent failed to do so on or before 30th April, 1971, the Pay and Accounts Officer, New Delhi Madras would be authorised to recover the, same from the pending bills of the respondent in respect of other companytracts.

facts.text: Respondent filed application under s.20 Arbitration Act in Delhi High Court to file arbitration agreement in cl.24.

anchor.surface_text: This dispute between the parties being a dispute arising out of the companytract was liable to be settled by arbitration under cl. 24 of the General Conditions of Contract and the respondent, therefore, filed an application. in the Delhi High Court under s. 20 of the Indian Arbitration Act for filing the Arbitration Agreement companytained in that clause.

facts.text: Delhi High Court rejected respondent's application for interim injunction as no pending bills shown.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent also, at the same time, made an application to the Delhi High Court for an interim injunction restraining the appellant from recovering the amount of damages claimed by it from the pending bills of the respondent. This application was, however, rejected by the Delhi High Court on the ground that it was number shown that there were any pending bills of the respondent at that time out of which the threatened recovery companyld be made by the appellant.

facts.text: Delhi High Court by order dated 5th May 1972 allowed s.20 application and ordered reference to arbitration.

anchor.surface_text: The application under s. 20 of the Indian Arbitration Act was thereafter heard by the Delhi High Court and by an order dated 5th May, 1972 the Delhi High Court allowed that application and ordered the arbitration agreement companytained in cl. 24 to be filed and made an order of reference to arbitration in accordance with the arbitration agreement.

facts.text: Respondent filed Interim Application No. 119 of 1972 on 17th January 1972 under s.41 with Second Schedule for injunction against recovery from pending bills.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, therefore, made interim Application No. 119 of 1972 to the Delhi High Court on 17th January, 1972 under s. 41 read with the Second Schedule to the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940 praying that the status quo should be maintained and the appellant should be restrained from recovering its claim for damages from the amounts due and payable by the appellant to the respondent in respect of the pending bills.

facts.text: Respondent filed another Interim Application No. 746 of 1972 on 16th May 1972 as independent application for same relief.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, in view of this technical objection raised on behalf of the appellant, filed another Interim Application No. 746 of 1972 as an independent application under s. 41 read with the Second Schedule to the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940 on 16th May, 1972 praying for the same interim relief as was claimed in the earlier Interim Application No. 119 of 1972.

facts.text: Delhi High Court by order dated 15th November 1972 allowed interim applications and granted injunction restraining appellant from recovering from pending bills.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge accordingly by an order dated 15th November, 1972 allowed both the interim applications and issued an interim injunction restraining the appellant from effecting recovery of the amounts claimed to be due from- the other pending bills of the respondent.

facts.text: Appellant preferred Civil Appeals Nos. 1224 and 1225 of 1973 against Delhi HC order dated 15th November 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon, with certificates obtained from the Delhi High Court, preferred Civil Appeals Nos. 1224 and 1225 of 1973 in this Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that clause 18 does not entitle purchaser to appropriate sums due under other contracts towards unadjudicated claim for damages.

anchor.surface_text: A claim for damages for breach of companytract is, therefore, number a claim for a sum presently due and payable and the purchaser is number entitled, in exercise of the right companyferred upon it under cl. 18, to recover the amount of such claim by appropriating other sums due to the companytractor.

facts.text: Delhi High Court was justified in issuing interim injunction restraining appellant from appropriating pending bills towards damages claim.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the appellant had numberright or authority under cl. 18 to appropriate the amounts of other pending bills of the respondent in or towards satisfaction of its claim for damages against the respondent and the learned Judge was justified in issuing an interim Injunction restraining the appellant from doing so.

issues.text: Whether cl. 18 of the General Conditions of Contract permits the purchaser to recover a disputed claim for damages by appropriating sums due to the contractor under the contract or other contracts before adjudication

anchor.surface_text: These appeals, raise an interesting question relating to the interpretation of cl. 18 of the General Conditions of Contract contained in the Standard Form of Contract No. D.G.S. D. 68. That is the standard form in which contracts are entered into by the Central Purchase Organisation of the Government of India for purchase of stores from third parties described as contractors and the question of interpretation which arises for determination is, therefore, one of some importance,

issues.text: Whether the court had jurisdiction under s. 41(b) read with the Second Schedule to the Arbitration Act to grant an interim injunction restraining appropriation of dues pending arbitration

anchor.surface_text: The impugned order amounted in effect and substance to an order directing the appellant to pay the amounts of the pending bills of the respondent in respect of the other contracts and since the question of payment of the amounts of such pending bills did not form the subject matter of the reference which was pending before the arbitrator., the learned Judge had no jurisdiction under s. 41 read with the Second Schedule to make such an order and the impugned order was, therefore, outside the scope of his power and hence invalid.

issues.text: Whether a claim for damages (liquidated or unliquidated) arising from breach of contract constitutes a 'sum due' or debt recoverable under cl. 18 without prior adjudication

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, read the words any claim for the payment of a sum of money occurring in the opening part of cl. 18 not in isolation but in the context of the whole clause, for the intention of the parties is to be gathered not from one part of the clause or the other but from the clause taken as a whole.

issues.text: Whether the interim injunction could be granted merely because the claim for damages is disputed and pending adjudication, or only if prima facie not well-founded and balance of convenience requires it

anchor.surface_text: of course, it would be open to the court even in such a case to grant interim injunction, if it is satisfied that the claim for damages is prima facie not well founded and the balance of convenience requires that, Pending adjudication, the purchaser should be restrained

issues.text: Whether cl. 18 applies only to admitted claims or claims adjudicated upon, or to any claim including disputed unadjudicated damages

anchor.surface_text: the respondent, however, disputed the validity of this construction placed on cl. 18 by the appellant and contended that though the words used in the opening part of cl. 18 are any claim for the payment of a sum of money, which are general words of apparently wide amplitude sufficient to cover even a claim for damages arising out the contract,

arguments.claim: The impugned order directing interim injunction is outside jurisdiction under s.41(b) read with Second Schedule as it effectively directs payment of pending bills unrelated to arbitration proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The impugned order amounted in effect and substance to an order directing the appellant to pay the amounts of the pending bills of the respondent in respect of the other contracts and since the question of payment of the amounts of such pending bills did not form the subject matter of the reference which was pending before the arbitrator., the learned Judge had no jurisdiction under s. 41 read with the Second Schedule to make such an order and the impugned order was, therefore, outside the scope of his power and hence invalid.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ay the amounts due to the respondent under other companytracts. It is number only in form but also in substance a negative injunction. It has numberpo

arguments.court_reasoning: Order is negative injunction restraining appropriation, not directing payment; relates to claim in arbitration

arguments.claim: Clause 18 entitles purchaser to recover any claim including disputed damages by appropriating sums due under contract or other contracts without prior adjudication

anchor.surface_text: Clause 18 comes into play when there is a claim for payment of a sum of money arising out of or under the contract. It is not necessary that the sum of money must be due and payable to the purchaser. It is enough if there is a claim even for damages. Whenever, there is such claim, the purchaser is given a right under cl. 18 to recover it by appropriating any sum then due or which at any time thereafter may become due to the contractor under the contract or under any other contract.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nd culminates in a decree. The appellant in the present case had companysequently numberright under cl. 18 to appropriate sums due to the respondent u

arguments.court_reasoning: Cl.18 limited to sums presently due and payable; claim for damages not a debt until adjudicated; supported by heading, context, debt definition

arguments.claim: Interim injunction cannot be granted merely because damages claim is disputed and pending; only if prima facie not well-founded and balance of convenience requires

anchor.surface_text: No interim injunction could be granted to prevent the exercise of such right. If interim injunction were to be granted in a case of this kind as of course merely on the ground, without anything more, that the claim for damages is pending adjudication and until it is determined in favour of the purchaser, it should not be allowed to be recovered by the purchaser out of other sums due to the contractor, it would render cl. 18 meaningless and ineffectual and the right to the purchaser under that clause would become illusory. of course, it would be open to the court even in such a case to grant interim injunction, if it is satisfied that the claim for damages is prima facie not well founded and the balance of convenience requires that, Pending adjudication, the purchaser should be restrained

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle accepted but here claim prima facie not well-founded as damages not debt under cl.18

arguments.claim: Cl.18 only covers claims for sums due and payable, not disputed damages until admitted or adjudicated

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, however, disputed the validity of this construction placed on cl. 18 by the appellant and contended that though the words used in the opening part of cl. 18 are any claim for the payment of a sum of money, which are general words of apparently wide amplitude sufficient to cover even a claim for damages arising out the contract,

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nd culminates in a decree. The appellant in the present case had companysequently numberright under cl. 18 to appropriate sums due to the respondent u

arguments.court_reasoning: Words read in context of whole clause, heading 'Recovery of Sums Due', debt requires present obligation

arguments.claim: Damages claim (liquidated or unliquidated) does not become debt until adjudicated; mere right to sue

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 74 of the Indian Contract Act eliminates the some-what elaborate refinements made under the English common law in distinguishing between stipulations providing for payment of liquidated damages and stipulations in the nature of penalty... It, therefore makes no difference in the present case that the claim of the appellant is for liquidated damages. It stands on the same footing as a claim for unliquidated damages.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the Indian Contract Act eliminates the some-what elaborate refinements made under the English companymon law in distinguishing between stipulations pr

arguments.court_reasoning: Confirmed by s.74 Contract Act, TP Act s.6(e), English and Indian precedents; no pecuniary liability till court fiat

arguments.claim: Cl.18 does not authorize appropriation of pending bills towards damages unless claim admitted or adjudicated

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Justice Avadh Bihari of the Delhi High Court, who heard these interim application, took the view that cl. 18 did not authorise the appellant to appropriate. the amounts of any pending bills of the respondent towards satisfaction of its claim for damages against the respondent, unless such claim for damages was either admitted by the respondent or adjudicated upon by arbitration or suit in civil court.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion for the injury sustained by him, the stipulated amount being merely the outside limit. It, therefore makes numberdifference in the present case th

arguments.court_reasoning: SC holds same view on cl.18 interpretation; injunction justified

arguments.claim: Words 'any claim for payment of sum of money' in cl.18 must be read in context of whole clause, not isolation; refers to sums due/payable

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, read the words any claim for the payment of a sum of money occurring in the opening part of cl. 18 not in isolation but in the context of the whole clause, for the intention of the parties is to be gathered not from one part of the clause or the other but from the clause taken as a whole.

arguments.claim: Heading 'Recovery of Sums Due' indicates cl.18 deals with presently payable sums

anchor.surface_text: The first thing that strikes one on looking at cl. 18 is its heading which reads Recovery of Sums Due. It is true that a heading cannot control the interpretation of a clause if its meaning is otherwise plain and unambiguous, but it can certainly be referred to

arguments.claim: Debt/sum due requires present obligation to pay now or future (debitum in praesenti); damages claim not debt till adjudicated

anchor.surface_text: The classical definition of debt is to be found in Webb v. Stenton where Lindley, L. J., said a debt is a sum of money which is now payable or will become payable in the future by reason of a present obligation.

arguments.claim: Cl.18 provides mode of recovery for presently due sums only; not creating lien but right to appropriate recoverable claims

anchor.surface_text: It is merely intended to provide a mode of recovery of a claim for payment of a sum of money arising out of or under the contract. It, therefore, postulates a claim for a sum which is due and payable, that is. presently recoverable and may be recovered by the mode therein provided.

arguments.claim: Prior standard form change from 'recoverable and payable' to 'any claim' irrelevant for interpreting current cl.18

anchor.surface_text: We do not think it is legitimate to construe cl. 18 of the contract between the parties by reference to a corresponding clause which prevailed in an earlier Standard Form of Contract.

arguments.claim: S.74 Contract Act treats liquidated/unliquidated damages same; no debt till adjudication

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 74 of the Indian Contract Act eliminates the some-what elaborate refinements made under the English common law...

arguments.claim: Interim injunction under s.41 valid as restrains recovery of unadjudicated claim in arbitration

anchor.surface_text: The Court has, therefore power under s.41 b read with the Second Schedule to issue interim injunction, but such interim injunction can only be for the purpose of and in relation to arbitration proceedings... That is clearly Within the power of the Court under s. 41 b because the claim for damages forms the subject matter of the arbitration proceedings

holdings.text: The order of interim injunction made by the learned Judge cannot, therefore, be said to be outside the scope of his power under s. 41(b) read with the Second Schedule as it restrains appropriation of sums due towards the claim which is the subject matter of arbitration proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: The order of interim injunction made by the learned Judge cannot, therefore, be said to be outside the scope of his power under s. 41 b read with the Second Schedule

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order is negative injunction preventing recovery related to arbitrable claim, not directing payment of unrelated bills; within s.41(b) for purpose of arbitration.

holdings.text: Clause 18 applies only where the purchaser has a claim for a sum presently due and payable by the contractor.

anchor.surface_text: So viewed, it is clear that cl. 18 applies only where the purchaser has a claim for a sum presently due and payable by the contractor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction reading clause as whole, informed by heading 'Recovery of Sums Due', definition of debt requiring present obligation, purpose as mode of recovery for existing claims.

holdings.text: A claim for damages for breach of contract is not a claim for a sum presently due and payable and the purchaser is not entitled under cl. 18 to recover it by appropriating other sums due to the contractor.

anchor.surface_text: A claim for damages for breach of contract is, therefore, not a claim for a sum presently due and payable and the purchaser is not entitled, in exercise of the right conferred upon it under cl. 18, to recover the amount of such claim by appropriating other sums due to the contractor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Damages claim (liquidated or unliquidated per s.74 Contract Act) creates no debt until adjudicated; mere right to sue; supported by precedents on debt and actionable claims.

holdings.text: The appellant had no right or authority under cl. 18 to appropriate the amounts of other pending bills of the respondent towards its claim for damages and the learned Judge was justified in issuing the interim injunction.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the appellant had no right or authority under cl. 18 to appropriate the amounts of other pending bills of the respondent in or towards satisfaction of its claim for damages against the respondent and the learned Judge was justified in issuing an interim Injunction restraining the appellant from doing so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of cl.18 interpretation to facts: unadjudicated damages not recoverable by appropriation; injunction proper.

holdings.text: It is not legitimate to construe cl. 18 by reference to a corresponding clause in an earlier Standard Form of Contract.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think it is legitimate to construe cl. 18 of the contract between the parties by reference to a corresponding clause which prevailed in an earlier Standard Form of Contract.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract interpretation based on language in context, not prior versions; unlike statutory changes implying intent.

holdings.text: Interim injunction may be granted even against exercise of cl.18 right if claim for damages is prima facie not well-founded and balance of convenience requires restraint pending adjudication.

anchor.surface_text: of course, it would be open to the court even in such a case to grant interim injunction, if it is satisfied that the claim for damages is prima facie not well founded and the balance of convenience requires that, Pending adjudication, the purchaser should be restrained

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges limit to routine injunctions to preserve cl.18 efficacy, but allows on prima facie weakness (as here).

anchor.surface_text: The classical definition of debt is to be found in Webb v. Stenton  1  where Lindley, L. J., said a debt is a sum of money which is number payable or will become payable in the future by reason of a present obligation. There must be debitum in praesenti solvendum maybe

precedents.cited_proposition: classical definition of debt: a sum of money which is now payable or will become payable in the future by reason of a present obligation; debitum in praesenti, solvendum in praesenti or in futuro
precedents.cited_holding: a debt is a sum of money which is now payable or will become payable in the future by reason of a present obligation. There must be debitum in praesenti solvendum maybe in praesenti or in future

anchor.surface_text: The following passage from the judgment of the Supreme Court of California in People v. Arguello.  2  which, was approved by this Court in Kesoram Industries v. Commissione of Wealth Tax  3  clearly brings out the essential characteristics of a debt Standing alone, the word debt, is as applicable to a sum of money which has been promised at a future day as to a sum number due and payable.

precedents.cited_proposition: distinction between debt owing (future obligation) and debt due (presently payable obligation)
precedents.cited_holding: Standing alone, the word debt, is as applicable to a sum of money which has been promised at a future day as to a sum now due and payable. If we wish to distinguish between the two, we say of the former that it is a debt owing, and of the latter that it is debt due.

precedents.citation: Kesoram Industries v. Commissione of Wealth Tax  3

anchor.surface_text: which, was approved by this Court in Kesoram Industries v. Commissione of Wealth Tax  3  clearly brings out the essential characteristics of a debt Standing alone, the word debt, is as applicable to a sum of money which has been promised at a future day as to a sum number due and payable. If we wish to distinguish between the two, we say of the former that it is. a debt owing, and of the latter that it is debt due.

precedents.case_name: Kesoram Industries v. Commissioner of Wealth Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: approved the distinction between debt owing and debt due as stated in People v. Arguello

anchor.surface_text: in England and as far back as 1858 we, find it stated by Wightman, J., in Jones v. Thompson  1  Exparte Charles and several other cases decide that the amount of a verdict in an action for unliquidated damages is number a debt till judgment has. been signed It was held in this case that a claim for damages dots number become a debt even after the jury has returned a verdict in favour of the plaintiff till the judgment is actually delivered.

precedents.cited_proposition: a claim for unliquidated damages does not become a debt even after verdict until judgment is signed
precedents.cited_holding: the amount of a verdict in an action for unliquidated damages is not a debt till judgment has been signed

precedents.citation: O Driscoll v. Manchester Insurance Committee, 2

anchor.surface_text: So also in O Driscoll v. Manchester Insurance Committee, 2  Swinfen Eady, L. J., said in reference to cases where the claim was for unliquidated damages in such cases there is numberdebt at all until the verdict of the jury is pronounced assessing the damages and judgment is given. The same view has also been taken companysistently by different High Courts in India.

precedents.case_name: O Driscoll v. Manchester Insurance Committee
precedents.cited_proposition: no debt at all in cases of unliquidated damages until verdict assessing damages and judgment given
precedents.cited_holding: in such cases there is no debt at all until the verdict of the jury is pronounced assessing the damages and judgment is given

anchor.surface_text: The same view has also been taken companysistently by different High Courts in India. We may mention only a few of the decisions, namely, Jabed Sheikh v. Taher Mallik, 3  S. Malkha Singh v. M s N. K. Gopala Krishna Mudaliar 4  and Iron Hardware  India  Co. v. Firm Shamlal Bros. 5

anchor.surface_text: S. Malkha Singh v. M s N. K. Gopala Krishna Mudaliar 4  and Iron Hardware  India  Co. v. Firm Shamlal Bros. 5   1  1858 27 L. J. Q.B. 234.  3  45 Cal. Weekly Notes, 519.  2  1915 3 K. D. 499.  4  1956 A.I.R. Pun. 174.  5  1954 A.I.R. Bom. 423. Chagla, C. J. in the last mentioned case, stated the law in these terms In my opinion it would number be true to say that a person who companymits a breach of the companytract incurs any pecuniary liability...

precedents.case_name: Iron Hardware India Co. v. Firm Shamlal Bros.
precedents.cited_proposition: no pecuniary liability arises till the court determines liability and assesses damages; claim for damages is not a debt until then
precedents.cited_holding: In my opinion it would not be true to say that a person who commits a breach of the contract incurs any pecuniary liability, nor would it be true to say that the other party... has any amount due to him... The only right which he has is the right to go to a Court of law and recover damages... no pecuniary liability arises till the Court has determined that the party complaining of the breach is entitled to damages.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, hold that the appellant had no right or authority under cl. 18 to appropriate the amounts of other pending bills of the respondent in or towards satisfaction of its claim for damages against the respondent and the learned Judge was justified in issuing an interim Injunction restraining the appellant from doing so.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant had no right under cl. 18 to appropriate amounts of other pending bills of the respondent towards its claim for damages; learned Judge was justified in issuing interim injunction restraining the appellant from doing so

anchor.surface_text: A claim for damages for breach of contract is, therefore, not a claim for a sum presently due and payable and the purchaser is not entitled, in exercise of the right conferred upon it under cl. 18, to recover the amount of such claim by appropriating other sums due to the contractor.
